Genesis—Fable And Facts
"Why, Grandma, what big shoes you've got!"
"The better for you to fill, my dear!"
And so Grandma, in the form of the editor and
his senior associates, plays the part of the fabulous
and recently revived big, bad wolf to perfection by
arising from bed and allowing herself to be laid low
by Father Time, after having had her fling at terrorizing the inhabitants of the immediate vicinity.
And Little Red Riding Hood, her innocent features
betraying a marked hot-tor as the result of what has
just transpired, is left on the scene alone. Alone,
did we say? Well, not quite—for in this case the
wolf has left behind his shoes and she is expected to
fill them.
We don't hold any br
.ief for the red-cloaked one
of story-book fame; in fact, we admire far more the
shrewdness of Brother Wolf as evinced in his excellent replies to her startled exclamations relative to
his physiognomy. But we can't help likening her
expression of bewilderment and fright upon learning
that "Grandma doesn't live here any more" to the
reaction that was produced within us upon the realization that we, the new editor and staff, have been
charged with the responsibility of picking up and
carrying on where our predecessors left off.
For the shoes which they bequeathed unto us
are certainly of monstrous proportions. In them reside such phantom figures as Student Activities Council, Athletic Association, faculty, fraternities, R. 0.
T. C., and Black and Blue Jay—each, no doubt, waiting with bated breath to discover whether our first
words with regard to it will signify approbation or
disapproval. And to stretch such already crowded
shoes beyond their normal capacity, the retiring staff
tosses in a final (and perhaps most deadly) element
for good measure—the College for Teachers and its
apparent lack of pulchritude. We are willing and
ready to face our masculine brethren in the open,
but to tell a woman she just isn't good-looking—gentlemen, we enlist your sympathy!
In spite of this obvious injustice, we wish to express our commendation and appreciation to the old
guard as a whole, and to Editor Norman S. Heaney
in particular. Here was a man who belied the most
fundamental principle in the newspaper game; he
managed to perform his daily chores without once
ever tearing his hair, invoking the Deity, or giving
vent to wrathful invectives, as the Barnstormers
would have us believe. We always secretly wondered
if his name weren't Normal instead of Norman, for
he was the height of unobtrusiveness, authoritativeness, and efficiency in all of his actions. It is with
the fond hope that we can emulate his example that
we enter upon our year of grace.
As to our platform, it can be summed up in the
followirrx planks:
1—To
b be constructive in all of our criticisms
2—To commend as well as condemn
3—To improve THE NEWS-LETTER wherever
possible in order to make it more and more
a publication of the students, by the students,
and for the students
4—To further the best interests of the Johns Hopkins University at all times.
Thus our Genesis. Let there be Light!

A Rushing Business
Fraternities as a whole are useful things, but like
useful things they can be often misused. The phase
of their mismanagement that we introduce here centers upon their effect in serving upon occasion as a
direct and derogatory influence in the formation of
the freshman's future career. We've seen it occur
many times and by now have resigned ourselves to
the conclusion that it is an individual, and perhaps
largely incurable, matter. Still, it's certainly worth
citing.
A freshman enters the University usually no more
certain with regard to where his academic interests
lie than the cafeteria prices are of ever reaching anywhere near moderate figures. He enrolls in one of
the three schools, maps out a schedule with the aid of
an advisor who cannot possibly be expected to probe
his innermost depths and hope to find therein some
peculiarly ignited spark of genius, and attends classes

more or less faithfully until the midyear exams are
over and Egypt to him represents nothing more than
Cleopatra's backyard.
At this crucial stage in his university existence,
he suddenly finds himself a victim of the change of
seasons—"rushing season", with its attendant hot air,
has quelled the frigid blasts of winter. He gets an
"invite" from one fraternity, composed in the main,
let us say, of English majors, discovers that the members are quite congenial, and is duly pledged and initiated. Unconsciously, since there is no restraining
force to detain him, he gradually decides that perhaps
he really was cut out to appreciate the "Wasp of
Twickenham" and to penetrate the metaphysical implications of Donne. Other fields may be all right,
he reasons, but after all, this isn't half bad and I'll
be taking the same courses as the rest of the boys.
Why change?—He doesn't change.
These cases are not so numerous as to nullify
the unquestionable benefits which the fraternity offers
the young man seeking an education. Many of them
boast a membership of students equall y divided among
the three schools. Nevertheless, the fact remains that
rushing a freshman who may still be blindly groping
his way through a mist of uncertainty often tends
to produce an unhappy result. Perhaps a suspension
of "rushing season" until the first-year men get their
bearings would largely do away with such cases. Or
might it be possible that after one year of college
life the individual would find himself able to get
along very nicely without a fraternity at all?

Genesis—Fable And Facts
"Why, Grandma, what big shoes you've got!"
"The better for you to fill, my dear!"
And so Grandma, in the form of the editor and
his senior associates, plays the part of the fabulous
and recently revived big, bad wolf to perfection by
arising from bed and allowing herself to be laid low
by Father Time, after having had her fling at terrorizing the inhabitants of the immediate vicinity.
And Little Red Riding Hood, her innocent features
betraying a marked hot-tor as the result of what has
just transpired, is left on the scene alone. Alone,
did we say? Well, not quite—for in this case the
wolf has left behind his shoes and she is expected to
fill them.
We don't hold any br
.ief for the red-cloaked one
of story-book fame; in fact, we admire far more the
shrewdness of Brother Wolf as evinced in his excellent replies to her startled exclamations relative to
his physiognomy. But we can't help likening her
expression of bewilderment and fright upon learning
that "Grandma doesn't live here any more" to the
reaction that was produced within us upon the realization that we, the new editor and staff, have been
charged with the responsibility of picking up and
carrying on where our predecessors left off.
For the shoes which they bequeathed unto us
are certainly of monstrous proportions. In them reside such phantom figures as Student Activities Council, Athletic Association, faculty, fraternities, R. 0.
T. C., and Black and Blue Jay—each, no doubt, waiting with bated breath to discover whether our first
words with regard to it will signify approbation or
disapproval. And to stretch such already crowded
shoes beyond their normal capacity, the retiring staff
tosses in a final (and perhaps most deadly) element
for good measure—the College for Teachers and its
apparent lack of pulchritude. We are willing and
ready to face our masculine brethren in the open,
but to tell a woman she just isn't good-looking—gentlemen, we enlist your sympathy!
In spite of this obvious injustice, we wish to express our commendation and appreciation to the old
guard as a whole, and to Editor Norman S. Heaney
in particular. Here was a man who belied the most
fundamental principle in the newspaper game; he
managed to perform his daily chores without once
ever tearing his hair, invoking the Deity, or giving
vent to wrathful invectives, as the Barnstormers
would have us believe. We always secretly wondered
if his name weren't Normal instead of Norman, for
he was the height of unobtrusiveness, authoritativeness, and efficiency in all of his actions. It is with
the fond hope that we can emulate his example that
we enter upon our year of grace.
As to our platform, it can be summed up in the
followirrx planks:
1—To
b be constructive in all of our criticisms
2—To commend as well as condemn
3—To improve THE NEWS-LETTER wherever
possible in order to make it more and more
a publication of the students, by the students,
and for the students
4—To further the best interests of the Johns Hopkins University at all times.
Thus our Genesis. Let there be Light!

A Rushing Business
Fraternities as a whole are useful things, but like
useful things they can be often misused. The phase
of their mismanagement that we introduce here centers upon their effect in serving upon occasion as a
direct and derogatory influence in the formation of
the freshman's future career. We've seen it occur
many times and by now have resigned ourselves to
the conclusion that it is an individual, and perhaps
largely incurable, matter. Still, it's certainly worth
citing.
A freshman enters the University usually no more
certain with regard to where his academic interests
lie than the cafeteria prices are of ever reaching anywhere near moderate figures. He enrolls in one of
the three schools, maps out a schedule with the aid of
an advisor who cannot possibly be expected to probe
his innermost depths and hope to find therein some
peculiarly ignited spark of genius, and attends classes

more or less faithfully until the midyear exams are
over and Egypt to him represents nothing more than
Cleopatra's backyard.
At this crucial stage in his university existence,
he suddenly finds himself a victim of the change of
seasons—"rushing season", with its attendant hot air,
has quelled the frigid blasts of winter. He gets an
"invite" from one fraternity, composed in the main,
let us say, of English majors, discovers that the members are quite congenial, and is duly pledged and initiated. Unconsciously, since there is no restraining
force to detain him, he gradually decides that perhaps
he really was cut out to appreciate the "Wasp of
Twickenham" and to penetrate the metaphysical implications of Donne. Other fields may be all right,
he reasons, but after all, this isn't half bad and I'll
be taking the same courses as the rest of the boys.
Why change?—He doesn't change.
These cases are not so numerous as to nullify
the unquestionable benefits which the fraternity offers
the young man seeking an education. Many of them
boast a membership of students equall y divided among
the three schools. Nevertheless, the fact remains that
rushing a freshman who may still be blindly groping
his way through a mist of uncertainty often tends
to produce an unhappy result. Perhaps a suspension
of "rushing season" until the first-year men get their
bearings would largely do away with such cases. Or
might it be possible that after one year of college
life the individual would find himself able to get
along very nicely without a fraternity at all?

the anatomical, but lies much
deeper, in the realm of the subconscious.

his presence seems to conjure up
in his mind pictures of huge
wriggling boa constrictors which
will crush one to a mass of jelly, or
long cobras whose bite means a
long and tortured death.
This conclusion was unexpect
edly reached one day last year
when an unobtrusive, laboring
freshman candidate appeared in
the locker rooms with a common
variety of garden snake wriggling
